question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In this scenario, I am tasked with estimating the probabilities of various questions related to Donald Trump Jr.'s potential candidacy and nomination for the 2024 US Presidential Election. The questions are closely interrelated, particularly those involving P (the probability of Trump Jr. being the nominee), not_P (the probability of him not being the nominee), and Q (the probability of him running for a different political office). 

1. **P (Donald Trump Jr. being the Republican nominee)**: This probability is influenced by various factors, including the political climate, his popularity within the party, and the competition he faces. Given his last name and political connections, I estimate a moderate probability of around 0.60.

2. **not_P (Donald Trump Jr. not being the Republican nominee)**: This is simply the complement of P. If I estimate P at 0.60, then not_P would be 0.40.

3. **para_P (Donald Trump Jr. as the candidate)**: This question is essentially the same as P, so I will keep it consistent with P, thus estimating it at 0.60.

4. **Q (Donald Trump Jr. running for a different political office)**: This probability is somewhat independent of P, as he could choose to run for another office regardless of his nomination status. However, if he is heavily focused on being the nominee, the probability of him running for another office might be lower. I estimate this at 0.30.

5. **P_and_Q (Both being the nominee and running for another office)**: This is a conjunction of P and Q. If P is at 0.60 and Q is at 0.30, I need to consider the independence of these events. Given the nature of political campaigns, I estimate this at 0.18.

6. **P_or_Q (Either being the nominee or running for another office)**: This is a union of P and Q. Using the estimates for P and Q, I calculate this as P + Q - P_and_Q. This results in 0.60 + 0.30 - 0.18 = 0.72.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Running for another office and not being the nominee)**: This is a conditional probability that needs careful consideration. If he runs for another office, it may indicate he is not the nominee. I estimate this at 0.25.

8. **Q_given_P (Running for another office given he is the nominee)**: If he is the nominee, it is less likely he will run for another office. I estimate this at 0.10.

Overall, the estimates need to be consistent with the rules provided, such as the complement rule, conjunction, and disjunction rules. I will now verify these estimates against the consistency rules.

question.title: Will Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Asa Hutchinson is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently considered; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.title: Will both Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if both Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson are selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates or combinations will resolve as **No**. It is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In evaluating the probability estimates for the various questions regarding Donald Trump Jr.'s potential candidacy in the 2024 US Presidential Election, I considered several factors that could influence the outcomes of these questions. 

1. **P (Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?)**: This probability is influenced by the current political climate, Trump's popularity within the Republican Party, and any potential challengers. Given that Trump Jr. has a strong backing from a significant faction of the party, I estimate this probability to be moderately high.

2. **not_P (Will Donald Trump Jr. not be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?)**: This is the complement of P, and its probability is directly related to the uncertainty around his candidacy and the presence of other strong candidates. If I estimate P to be high, not_P must be correspondingly lower.

3. **para_P (Is Donald Trump Jr. going to be the Republican candidate for the 2024 US Presidential Election?)**: This question is essentially equivalent to P, thus I expect this probability to be very similar to that of P.

4. **Q (Will Donald Trump Jr. run for a different political office before 2024?)**: This depends on Trump Jr.'s political ambitions and the strategic decisions he makes regarding his future. If he is likely to run for another office, this probability should be higher.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both Donald Trump Jr. be selected as the Republican nominee and run for a different political office before 2024?)**: This question requires both P and Q to be true, so I would expect this probability to be lower than either P or Q alone.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee or run for a different political office before 2024?)**: This probability should be higher than either P or Q alone, reflecting the likelihood of at least one of these events occurring.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both Donald Trump Jr. run for a different political office before 2024 and not be the Republican nominee?)**: This probability will depend on the relationship between Q and not_P, indicating a scenario where he actively seeks another office while not being the nominee.

8. **Q_given_P (Given Donald Trump Jr. is the Republican nominee, will he run for a different political office before 2024?)**: This is a conditional probability that hinges on the assumption that if he is the nominee, he may not pursue another office. 

In terms of consistency rules, I need to ensure that the probabilities align correctly according to the mathematical relationships defined. For instance, the relationship between P and not_P must hold true, as must the relationships involving conjunctions (and) and disjunctions (or). Each probability estimate must also consider the potential dependencies between the questions, particularly between P and Q, as they could influence each other. 

Overall, the estimates are rooted in a combination of political analysis, current events, and party dynamics, while also adhering to the consistency checks required.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

For the question regarding Donald Trump Jr. being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election (P), I would consider factors such as his current popularity within the party, any endorsements he may receive, and the political landscape leading up to the convention. I would estimate a moderate probability for P, reflecting the uncertainty of the political process.

For not_P, this is simply the complement of P, so it should logically follow that if P is relatively high, not_P will be lower.

The para_P question is essentially a rephrasing of P, so I would assign it the same probability as P, given that they are logically equivalent.

For Q, which asks whether Donald Trump Jr. will run for a different political office before 2024, I would assess the likelihood based on his current political ambitions and any public statements he has made. This might be less likely than P if he is focused on the presidential nomination.

P_and_Q would depend on both P and Q being true, so I would estimate it as the product of their probabilities, assuming some independence but acknowledging that they may not be fully independent events.

P_or_Q would be the probability that at least one of P or Q is true, which can be calculated using the formula P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q.

For Q_and_not_P, this would require Q to be true while P is false, so I would estimate this based on the probabilities of Q and not_P.

Finally, Q_given_P would be a conditional probability reflecting the likelihood of Q given that P is true, which would likely be higher than the unconditional probability of Q since being the nominee might increase the likelihood of him running for another office.

Overall, I would ensure that my estimates adhere to the consistency rules, particularly those regarding complements, conjunctions, and disjunctions.

question.title: Will Kamala's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday August 9th at 8:40 PM. Resolves NO otherwise.

Link: https://www.natesilver.net/p/nate-silver-2024-president-election-polls-model

1. **P (Donald Trump Jr. being the Republican nominee)**: This probability will be influenced by various factors, including the political landscape, his popularity within the party, and potential challengers. Given the current political climate, I estimate this probability to be moderately high.

2. **not_P (Donald Trump Jr. not being the Republican nominee)**: This is simply the complement of P. If P is estimated at a certain probability, not_P will be calculated as 1 - P. 

3. **para_P (Is Donald Trump Jr. going to be the Republican candidate)**: This question is essentially the same as P, so I expect its probability to be equal to P.

4. **Q (Donald Trump Jr. running for a different political office)**: This question introduces a new variable. Given the uncertainty in political ambitions, this probability may be lower than P, but still plausible.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occurring)**: This probability requires both events to happen simultaneously. If P is high and Q is moderate, P_and_Q will depend on how these two events interact.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurring)**: This is a broader question that captures any scenario where either event happens, so its probability will typically be higher than both P and Q individually.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurring while not P)**: This scenario is interesting because it examines the situation where Donald Trump Jr. runs for a different office but is not the nominee. This probability is likely lower than Q alone, depending on the relationship between these two events.

8. **Q_given_P (Q occurring given P)**: This conditional probability looks at the likelihood of Q happening if P is true. If P is high, Q may still have a reasonable chance of occurring, but it depends on the political strategy of Donald Trump Jr.

In terms of independence, P and Q are not entirely independent since both relate to Donald Trump Jr.'s political aspirations. However, they can influence each other's probabilities. For instance, if he is the nominee (P), he may be less likely to run for another office (Q) before the election.

Overall, the estimates will need to respect the consistency rules to ensure a coherent set of probabilities.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President, and (2) Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:
(1) Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

This resolves Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

(2) Will Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?

This resolves YES if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday, August 9th, at 8:40 PM. Resolves NO otherwise.
